div3.p: The subscriber is authorized by the Secretary of War, to raise a Regiment of Infantry to serve for the war. All persons desirous of uniting with him in this enterprise are requested to call at the office of Col. P. J. Archer Commission Merchant, next to the corner of Cary and 18th sts.
div3.closer:
Thos. G. Peyton,
fe 21--2w Major Virginia Forces.

div3.head: Volunteers, attention!
div3.p:
An adjourned meeting of the citizens of Union and Church Hills will be held at Springfield Hall, on this (Friday) evening, at 7½ o'clock, to form a Volunteer Company for the war. Come one!
come all!
Fifty dollars bounty and uniforms furnished.
A large attendance is desired.
fe 21--11*

div3.head:
Light Artillery!!
Battery secured!!!
bounty Fifty Dollars!
div3.p: The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia, for the war. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $30 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at, once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 1th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
div3.closer:
Stapleton Crutchfield,
William E. Tanner,
Charles E. Wortham.
fe 18--ts

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 45, page 3.

div3.head: Matrimony in France.
div3.p:
A case throwing light on the curious state of Parisian society has just been tried before the Civil Tribunal.
It ran to some length but the facts are few and simple.
The Marquis de Trevelec, who was represented to belong to one of the noblest families in France, his ancestors having figured in the Crusades, was some time ago anxious to marry, and as his exconquer is not flourishing he required a young lady who, in addition to youth, beauty and virtue should possess wealth.
But though, from his rank and name, having access to the best society, both aristocratic and financial, of the capital, he doubled that he could himself had a suitable damsel, and so he charged a certain Madame Jolly de Montesson to seek out one for him, promising to pay her for her trouble.
This females, whose occupation is to negotiate marriages, introduced him to a respectable and rich family, in which was a young lady ready to wed. A marriage was resolved on, but, for some reason not stated, it was broken off. On that the Marquis de Trevelec prayed Madame Jolly de Montesson to resume her search for a wife for him, and she said that she knew two rich young ladies, sisters, Males A--, whose parents wanted husbands for them.
The Marquis has a brother, the Count de Trevelec, who was also desirous to marry, and an understanding was come to between them and Madame de Montesson that they pay her 600 pounds sterling each, if she could secure for them the hands of the two girls, with 12,000 pounds sterling fortune to each, and a lesser sum in the event of the fortune being less in the event of only one of the brothers being accepted 600 pounds sterling were to be paid by him alone.
This understanding was set forth in a deed drawn up and executed in, due form.

But the father of the girls, a retired trader, would not allow them to wed nobles, and so the affair fell to the ground.
Madame de Montesson, however, knew two other sisters, Mdlles.
B--, of the Ru.--, both pretty, both young, both rich, and to their family and to them the introduced the brothers, through the family physician.
The result was that the Marquis de Trevelec was accepted by, and in one time married to, the elder sister; but no catch was brought about between the younger girl and the younger brother.
After the marriage.
Madame de Montesson called on the Marquis de Trevelec to pay her £500, according to his agreement; but he refused, on the ground that he had only authorized her to negotiate a marriage with one of the Mdlles A--, and what she had nothing to do beyond getting him introduced by the doctor, with his marriage with Mdile B-- A great deal of angry correspondence took place between the but they could not agree, and the woman brought an as for £00. She, to support it, produced her agreement, which expressly said that she should be paid that sum in the event of her obtaining the marriage of the Marquis to one of the Mdiles.
A--, or one of the Mdiles.
B — But the Marquis maintained that the document was only applicable to the Mdiles A-- and that the words or the Mdiles.
B-- had been added after he had signed it

The tribunal, after weighing all the facts and reading all the correspondence in the case, came to the conclusion that the agreement was not applied to the marriage effected between the Marquis and the Mdlle.
B--;but it was through the plaintiff that he had become acquainted with her, and that he knew that she expected to be paid for her services.
It ordered him to give her £24. Such is the way marriages are made in high life in Paris.

div3.head: Acknowledgment.
div3.p: The Shriver Grays, a volunteer company from Wheeling, in the Stone-Wall brigade, desire to express their thanks to miss Dexta Hughes, of this city, for several presents of clothing, &c. this company of exiles, separated from mothers and sisters, have reason to remember with gratitude the considerate and generous kindness of Miss Hughes and other ladies known to them only by their patriotism and liberality.

Dav D M Shriver, Captain to G. 27th Reg't Va Vols.
Richmond Feb. 19, 1862

div3.head: Distress the English and French operatives.
div3.p:
--The distress among the operatives out of employment in the British manufacturing distress continues to increase; and we take up a Manchester or Liverpool or Glassgow journal that does not contain details of the most distressing description.
The poor-houses have daily additions to their inmates, and pauperism as rapidly on the increase.
As in England and Scotland, so in France.
In Sonen, of the 51,000 persons who live by spinning, weaving, and dyeing, two thirds can find nothing to do, and of these two thirds nearly all are working on half of quarter time.
The Government is doing much to alleviate the want and suffering resulting from this state of things, which journals unfriendly to the North are in the habit of representing as he consequence of but one cause — the blockade of the rebel ports by the Federal Government.
This allegation is no doubt true in part, but the way of putting it would be to say, it is the consequence of an attempt of the Southern conspirators to and destroy that Government.

div3.head: Predictions for 1862.
div3.p:
--The year 1862 will be a very eventin one to every mallen who gets married Throughout the whole course of the year, whenever the moan W the nights will grow dark Whoever is in love this year will think his mistress an angel. --Whoever gets married will find out whether it be true.
He that loses his hair this year will go bald.
He that loses his wife will become a widower If a young lady should happen to blush, she will look red in the face; if she dresses of a young man three nights in succession, it will be a sign of something, if she dreams of him four times, or have the toothache, it is tea to one that she is a long time out of her head.

The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be enlisted for the war. It is how obvious that all who can must beat arms in defence of their homes and firesides, and we deem it unnecessary to make any appeal to the true men of Virginia to enroll their names in vindication of a just and holy cause.
We therefore simple give notice that all who desire to join our company, can do to by applying at the office of Johnson & Guigon, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford, at once.
Uniforms will be furnished free.
div3.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford,
fe 20--1w Alexander B Guigon.

div4.p: With the undersigned have opened a recruiting office corner of 17 hand Marshall streets, for the purpose of raising one hundred men, either for infantry or artillery service, as the vote of the company may decide.

Notice.--Lieut A. W. Nolting, Jr., commanding the company, 179th Regiment Virginia Militia may be found at this recruiting office.
where he will be ready to receive the names of all persons within there bound: North corporation line; south, Broad street; east, 18th street; west, Shockoe creek.
fe 20--st *

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --A few more good and reliable men will be received for local service, in Battery No. 9, Brook Turnpike, If application be made at once either at the Battery or opposite the Spotswood Hotel, on Main street, where gentlemen will be found to and give any information required.
This is the last chance for enlistment in this branch of the service, as all of the batteries are supplied.
div3.closer:
T. P. Wilkinson,
Captain Comd'g Winder Batter.
fe 20--6t *

div3.head:
Attention!
Metropolitan Guards.
div3.p: --A meeting of our company will be held at Military Hall (over the First Market) on Friday evening, 21st inst., at 8 o'clock. The punctual attendance of every member, and those who may desire to join, is requested.

N. B.--twenty more good men will be admitted.
This company is for special service, and such persons as do not wish to leave the city would do well to join promptly before the muster roll is closed.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --All members of the Purcell Battery are required to report at Camp .
div3.closer:
R. L. Walker,
fe 20--2t * Captain Commanding.

div3.head: Headq'rs 9th Regiment A. Ma
div3.p:
order no. 16--Every male citizen between the ages of 18 and 45 not now in the active volunteer service and resident within the bounds of regiment, (extending from 10th street west to the Corporation line) whether exempt from military duty or not will forthwith report him. sell for enrollment, to the captain of his company.
Those claiming to be exempt will also report the claim to or cause of such exemption.
The law of Virginia, passed on the 8th of February, 1862, provides.
If any person liable to military oust shall fall to have his name by the officer appointed for that purpose for ten days after the notice or proclamation requiring such enrollment shall have been posted or published at two or more public places in his ward or magisterial district, he shall, unless there be a sufficient excuse for such failure, be enrolled or drafted among the first levies to be drawn from such county or corporation.
The Adjutant General, in his order of the 13th, says: "Falling in the enrollment of their name,) the penally imposed by law will be strictly enforced"

The notice requiring such enrollment has been posted as press by law. No previous enrollment will answer the purpose.
Because of frequent changes from volunteering and other causes, the present company rolls, though recently made are not and the recent law requires a enrollment and citizens are required, although their names may be now on the rolls, to report themselves again for enrollment.

Those residing between 10th and 4th, and Broad and Cary sts., will report to Capt Wm.
F. At who may be found at the store of & Brother.

Those residing between Broad and Cary streets, and between 4th street and the western corporation line, will report to Capt. Ed. R. Morriss, to be found at the office of J. Pannill, at Shockoe Warehouse.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries; Commencing at the southwest corner of 4th and Cary sts.,; thence South side of Cary street to the corporation line; thence with the corporation line to the northwest side of J. R. and K canal; thence with the northwest side of the canal to its intersection with A street; thence with the south side of A street to 4th street and thence with the western side of 4th street to the beginning — will report to Capt. Che.
L Hobson, who may be found at the Snuff Factory, corner of 11th and Cary.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries; Commencing at the southern corner of 4th and Cary sts., thence south side of Cary street to 10th street; thence west side of 10th street to James river; thence James river to corporation line; thence with corporation line to the south side of the canal; thence with the south side of the canal to its intersection with A street and thence with the north side of A street to 4th street, and thence with the east side of 4th street to the beginning — will report to Capt. Wm. R. Sturdivant, who may be found at Galego Milis.

Those residing between 10th and 4th streets, and between Broad street and the northern corporation line, will report to Capt. Jno. F. Stagg, or Lieut. Courtney, who may be found on 6th, between Marshall and Clay streets.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries; Commencing at the northwest corner of Broad and 4th streets; thence with the north side of Broad to Adams Street; thence east side of Adams to Leigh street; thence north side of Leigh to Jefferson street; thence east side of Jefferson to Duval street; thence south side of Duval to 2d street; thence east side of 2d street to corporation line; thence with said line to 4th street, and thence west side of 4th street to the beginning — will reported Capt. S. T. Allen, on Marshall, between 6th and 7th streets.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries; Commencing at the northwest corner of 2d and Duval sts., thence north side of Duval street to Brook Avenue; thence east side of Brook Avenue to the corporation line; thence with corporation line to 2d street; thence with western side of 2d street to the beginning — will report to Captain Wm. J. Epps, who may be found at the City Hall.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries; Commencing at the corner of Broad and Adams street; thence north side of Broad street to corporation line; thence with corporation line to Brook Avenue; thence southwest side of Brook Avenue to Duval street; thence south side of Duval street to Jefferson street; thence west side of Jefferson st. to Leigh street; thence south side of Leigh street to Adams street, and thence western side of Adams street to the beginning — will report to Capt D. W. Saunders, who may be found at his room, head of Broad street.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Evans.
fe 13--3t * S. T. Pendleton, Adj't.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia to raise a battalion of five companies at least, each company numbering at least one hundred men, to be mustered into the service of the Confederate States for two years, if needed 50 long.

This battalion is for local defence and special service in the city of Richmond.
and not to be ordered away from this city.
This service is needed, or it would not be accepted.
Thus an opportunity is afforded to those.
the claims of whose families and other considerations would render is extremale inconvenient to be ordered away from Richmond, to serve their country without being subjected to this inconvenience.--That they will be called in some capacity, and that right soon, no one doubts.
Persons desiring to enlist can do so by calling on the officers of the 19th regiment, or at my office No. 1 Balvin's Block, 12th street.
Unless this battalion be raised and organized at once, the opportunity of securing the advantage above named may be last.
div3.closer:
Thos. J. Evans,
fe 19--3t * Colonel 19th Regiment.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of baring arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid u. in getting it up.

We want, if possible.
of raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns and think enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of 810 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at that warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co. 's, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The travailing expenses of residing from the country to the city will be paid.
div3.closer:
William G. Crenshaw,
James Ellett,
Charles L. Hobson,
fe 18--ts Andrew B. Johnston.

div3.head:
Adj't and Insp'r Gen's office,
[Extract] Richmond,Jan. 27, 1862
special Orders no. 22.
div3.p:
VIII. Lieutenant Colonel George Deas, Assistant adjutant General, is assigned to duty in the Adjutant Inspector General's office, and will take charge of the General Recruiting Service of the Army.
All communications pertaining to the recruiting service, will be marked, on the upper right hand side of the envelopes which cover them, "Recruiting Service."
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
Jno. Withers,
ja 28--1w Assistant Adjutant General.

div3.head: Headq'rs 19th Regiment Va. Ma.
div3.p:
order no. 11.--Every male citizen.
between the ages of 18 and 15, not now in the active volunteer service, and resident within the sounds of this regiment (extending from 10th street east to the. Corporation line) whether exempt from military duty or not, will forthwith report himself for enrollment to the Captain of his company.
Those claiming to be exempt will also report the claim to, or cause of such exemption.

The law of Virginia, passed on the 8th of February, 1861, provides.
"If any person liable to military duty shall fail to have his name enrolled by the officer appointed for that purpose, for ten days after the notice or proclamation requiring such enrollment, shall have been posted or published at two or more public places in his ward or magisterial district, he shall, unless there be a sufficient excuse for such failure, be enrolled or drafted among the first levies to be drawn iom such county or corporation"
The Adjutant General, in his order of the 19th, says: "Falling in this (the enrollment of their name) the penalty imposed by law will be strictly o"

The notice requiring such enrollment has been posted as required by law No previous enrollment will answer the purpose.
Because of frequent change from volunteering and other causes, the present company rolls, though recently made, are not now complete, and the recent law requires a new enrollment, and citizens are required, although their names may be now on the rolls, to report themselves again for enrollment.

First company is bounded as follows: East by Shockoe creek; north by corporation line; west by 10th street, and south by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain J. Beil Bigger, at the Post-Office.

Second company is bounded as follows: East by 18th street; north by corporation line; west by Shockoe creek; south by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Lieut. A. W. Norting, Jr., at Purcell, Ladd & Co.'s Drug Store.

Third company is bounded as follows: West by 10th street; south by James river; east by 12th street, and north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Lieut. P. B. Subletr, Shockoe Slip.
4th company is bounded as follows: West by 12th street, south by James river, east by 14th street and north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain J. M. Macon.

5th company is bounded as follows: West by 14th street, south by James river, east By 17th street. north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain Baldwin, opposite St. Charles Hotel.

6th company is bounded as follows: West by 17th street, South by James river, east by 20th street, north by Broad street. Those residing with in these limits will report to Captain James Moore, opposite St. Charles Hotel.

7th company is bounded as follows: West by 20th street, south by James river, east by 25th street. north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain Thomas F. Ragland, at Bridgford & Co.'s Cary street.

8th company is bounded as follows: West by 25th street, south by James river, east by corporation line, north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain Jonathan Swinney.
div3.closer:
By order of Robt. F. Morriss,
fe 19--3t * Colonel Commanding.

div3.head: Attention volunteers.
div3.p: --The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the Provisional Army of Virginia, for the War. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $50 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at once, either at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company, under the St. Charles Hotel, or at the Tredegar Works.
Those having substitutes, will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
div3.closer:
Stapleton Crutchfield,
William E. Tanner,
Charles E. Wortham.
fe 18--ts

div3.head: Attention volunteers,--$50 bounty.
div3.p:
Wanted to raise a Volunteer Company for artillery service.
Those wishing to join and thereby avoid the militia draft, and receive, besides, the $50 bounty, will apply to Mr. D. N. Walker, corner Shockoe Slip, or to the undersigned at Johnson, Younger & Otey's, 13 Pearl street.
div3.closer: fe 18--1wd G. G. Otey.

div3.head: To young Gentlemen
div3.p:
A Company of young Gentlemen, 16 to 18 years of age, is now forming for local defence.
This is an independent company and will be armed and thoroughly drilled with the "Lance," as Light Infantry.
Call and enroll at once at King & Son's, Scourers, &c., Main street, above 8th.

div3.head:
Hdqs.
Ordnance Dep't of Va.,
div3.p:
As there are get a large number of Flint Lock Muskets distributed over this state, those having them, in large or small numbers, are again urgently requested to send them in, to my Address, What they may be altered and put in good order.
ready for the use of the troops that will take the field next spring.
Each musket is of great value, as none can be bought, or made in the State.
div3.closer:
Chas. Dimmock,
ja 13--ts Col. of Ordnance of Va.,
City papers copy ts.

Adj't and Insp. Genl's office,

div3.head: $5 reward,
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on Saturday last, from my residence, at Rocketts, a Negro Girl, named Mary, black, 15 or 16 years old; belongs to Macon's estate.
I will give the above reward if delivered to me, or any where in Richmond.
fe 20--st * Thead Taylor.

div3.head: Runaway in Jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the Jail of the county of Hanover, on the 2d day of September last, as a runaway, a Negro Boy, calling himself Levi Bruington, who claims to be free.
The said Negro is of a dark complexion, and is about 5 feet 9 inches high, and is about 18 years of age, has a scar on right wrist and leg. The said Negro had on when committed a pair of brown Jeans pants and shirt, and a military cap, and is supposed to have escaped from some military company.
The owner of said Negro is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away, else he will be dealt with as the law directs.
C. S. Chisholme.
Acting Jailor of Hanover county, Va. ja 17--2aw6w

div3.head: Ranaway--$200 reward
div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov., Negro Boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5 ½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and nappy, and is left handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.
Louisa C. Taliaferro,
Rapid Ann P. O., Culpeper county, Va., de 12--d3t&eodts

div3.head: Runaway in Jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the Jail of the county of Hanover, on the 25th day of June last, as a runaway, a Negro Woman, calling herself Milly, and says she is the property of Peter Pulliam of the city of Richmond, Va. The said Negro is of a dark complexion, and is about four feet ten inches high, and about 60 years of age, and has a went on the right shoulder — a scar on same shoulder.
The said Negro had on when committed an ed brown Calico dress.
The owner of the said Negro is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take her away, else she will be dealt with as the law directs.
C. S. Chisholme,
Acting Jailor of Hanover county, Va., ja 17--2aw6w

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, has been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. E Herst, and the train left him at Burkesville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age, dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
J. W. Alsobrooks,
fe 17--1m * Will Town, Alabama.

div3.head: Runaway--$10 reward
div3.p:
--From Mr. Edwin S. Duval, about two weeks age, a negro slave named Wade.
He is about five feet eight inches in height, with long black hair, of very light complexion, and very pleasing in his manners.
The above reward will be paid on his delivery to me.
B. A. Cocke,
Office No. 4 Law Building,
fe 15--8t Franklin street.

div3.head: Committed to Jail as a runaway
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of the corporation of the City of Norfolk, on the 12th day of September, 1861, negro man Albert Brown.
The said negro man is five feet six and a half inches high, and weighs about 140 pounds, has a scar on the right arm about six inches long, dark complexion, and about twenty-five years old. Had on when committed gray clothing, and says he belongs to James Fisher.
Thomas J. Corprew,
fe 5--3w * Sergeant City of Norfolk.

div3.head: Ranaway--$25 reward
div3.p:
--A negro man named Gilbert, aged between 40 and 50 years. His color is black; whiskers grey, under the chin.
He is about six feet high; black hair.
His clothing is a black coat and plaid summer pants I bought him at Dickinson & Hill's auction room on Tuesday.
He was brought here by a gentleman named Thos. G. Neal, of North Carolina.
He left my premises Saturday afternoon, between and o'clock.
The above reward will be paid by
M. A. Myers, 66 Main street,
fe 3--1m * Or lodged in some convenient Jail.

div3.head: Fisty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the reward of fifty dollars for the delivery in Jail so that I get him, of my boy Moses, who ran off in July last, from Mr. Henry Massie, in Orange co., where he was hired.
He has been seen since in Caroline, and also at Mr. P A. Spotswood's, in Orange; where he has a wife.
He has relations in Prince William county, near Manassas.
He is about 25 years of age, five feet 9 inches in height, to dark ginger-bread color, with good front teeth, thick suit of hair, and eyes unusually red. M. P. O. is Fredericksburg, Va.
ja 22--1m Catlett Conway.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber my boy Henry, for whose apprehension and delivery to E. H. Stokes, of this place, or for his confinement in any jail, so that I gat him again, I will pay the above reward.
Henry is about 23 years old, black, about five feet three inches high, and has rather a down look when spoken to. Had on when he left black coat and pants, and black felt hat. He has been seen near Bristol, on the Manassas Gap Railroad, and near Cub Run Bridge.
He may be lurking around Dumfries or Richmond.
T. D. Carter,
ja 23--1m * for Dr. England.

div3.head: Matrimony in France.
div3.p:
A case throwing light of the curious state of Parisian society has just been tried before the Civil Tribunal.
It ran to some length but the fact are few and simple.
The Marquiside Trevelic, who was represented to be long to one of the noblest families in France, his ancestors having figured in the Crusades, was some time ago anxious to marry, and as his exchequer is not flourishing he required a young lady who, in addition to youth, beauty and virtue, should possess wealth.
But though, from his rank and name having access to the best society, both aristocratic and financial, of the capital, he doubted that he could himself find a suitable damsel, and so he charged a certain Madame Jolly de Monteson to seek out one for him, promising to pay her for her trouble.
This female, whose occupation is to negotiate marriages, introduced him to a respectable and rich family, in which was a young lady ready to wed. A marriage was resolved on, but, for some reason not stated, it was broked off. On that the Marquiside Trevelec prayed Madame Jolly de Montesson to resume her search for a wife for him, and she said that she knew two rich young ladies, sisters, Millies. A.--, whose parents wanted husbands for them.
The marquis has a brother, the Count de Trevelec, who was also desirous to marry, and an understanding was come to between them and Madame de Montesson that the pay her 500 pounds sterling each, of she could secure for them the hands of the two girls, with 12,000 pounds sterling fortune to each, and a lesser sum in the event of the fortune being less.
In the event of only one of the brothers being accepted 500 pounds sterling were to be paid by him alone.
This understanding was set forth in a deed drawn up and executed in due form.

But the father of the girls, a retired trader, would not allow them to wed nobles, and so the affair fell to the ground.
Madame de Montesson, however, knew two other sisters, Millies. B. --, of the Ru--,both pretty, both young, both rich, and to their family and to them she introduced the brothers, through the family physician.
The result was that the Marquis de Trevelec was accepted by, and in due time married to, the elder sister, but no union was brought about between the younger girl and the younger brother.
After the marriage.
Madame de Montesson called on the Marquis de Trevelec to pay her £600, according to his agreement; but he refused, on the ground that he had only authorized her to negotiate a marriage with one of the Maides --, and that she had nothing to do beyond getting him introduced by the doctor, with his marriage with Maides B.--A great deal of angry correspondence took place between the parties, but they could not agree, and the woman brought an action for £600.
She, to support it, produced her agreement, which expressly said that she should be paid that sum in the event of her obtaining the marriage of the Marquis to one of the Mdlies.A — or one of the Mdlies. B.--But the Marquis maintained that the document was only applicable to the Mdlies A.--. and that the words "or the Mdlies. B.--had been added after he had signed it.

The tribunal, after weighing all the facts and reading all the correspondence in the case, came to the conclusion that the agreement was not appointed the marriage effected between he Marquis and the Mdlie.
B--, but considering that it was through the plaintiff that he had become acquainted with her, and that he knew that she expected to be paid for her services, it ordered him to gave her £20.
Such is the way marriages are made in high life in Paris.

div3.head: Acknowledgment.
div3.p: The Shriver Grays, a volunteer company from Wheeling, in the Stone-Wall brigade, desire to express their thanks to miss Della Hughes, of this city, for several presents of clothing, &c. This company of exiles, separated from mothers and sisters, have reason to remember with gratitude the considerate and generous kindness of Miss Hughes and other ladies known to them only by their patriotism and liberality.
David. M Shriver.
Captain Co G, 27th Reg't Va Vols.
Richmond, Feb. 19, 1862.

div3.head: Distress among the English and French operatives.
div3.p:
--The distress among the operatives out of employment in the British manufacturing districts continues to increase; and we scarcely take up a Manchester or Liverpool or Glasgow journal that does not contain details of the most distressing description.
The poor houses have daily additions to their inmates, and pauperism is rapidly on the increase.
As in England and Scotland, so in France.
In Rouen, of the 50,000 persons who live by spinning, weaving, and dyeing, two thirds can find nothing to do, and of these two thirds nearly all are working on half of quarter time.
The Government is doing much to alleviate the want and suffering resulting from this state of things, which journals unfriendly to the North are in the habit of representing as he consequence of out one cause — the blockade of the rebel ports by the Federal Government.
This allegation is no doubt true inspire; but the fairer way of putting it would be to say, it is the consequence of an attempt of the Southern conspirators to upset and destroy that Government.

div3.head: Predictions for 1862.
div3.p:
--The year 1862 will be a very eventing one to every maiden who gets married.
Throughout the whole course of the year, whenever the moon wanes the nights will grow dark.
Whoever is in love this year will think his mistress an angel.--Whoever gets married will find out whether it be true.
He that loses his hair this year will go bald.
He that loses his wife will become a widower.
If a young lady should happen to blush, she will look red in the face; if she dreams of a young man three nights in succession, it will be a sign of something; if she dreams of him four times, or have the toothache, it is ten to one that she is a long time out of her head.

The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be enlisted for the war. It is now obvious that all who can must bear arms in defence of their homes and firesides, and we deem it unnecessary to make any appeal to the true men of Virginia to enroll their names in vindication of a just and holy cause.
We therefore simple give notice that all who desire to join our company, can do so by apply in at the office of Johnson & Guigon, or at the store of Johnston & Branford, at once.
Uniforms will be furnished face.
div3.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford,
fe 20--1w Alexander B. Guigon.

div4.p: Week the undersigned have opened a recruiting office corner of 17th and Marshall streets, for the purpose of raising one hundred men, either for infantry or artillery service, as the vote of the company may deems

div4.p:
--Lieut A. W. Nolting, Jr. commanding the 2d company, 179th Regiment Virginia Militia may be found at this recruiting office where he will be ready to receive the names of all persons filing within these bound: North corporation line; south, Road street; east, 18th street; west, Caje creek.
fe 20--2t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --A few more good and reliable men will be received for local service, in Battery No. 9, Brook Turnpike, if application be made at once either at the Battery or opposite the Spotswood Hotel, on Main street, where gentlemen will be found to enlist and give any information required.
This is the last chance for enlistment in this branch of the service, as all of the batteries are supplied.
div3.closer:
T. P. Wilkinson,
Captain Comd'g Winder Battery.
fe 20--6t

div3.head:
Attention!
Metropolitan Guards.
div3.p: --A meeting of our company will be held at Military Hall (over the First Market) on Friday evening, 21st inst., at 8 o'clock. The punctual attendance of every member, and those who may desire to join, is requested.

N. B.--twenty more good men will be admitted.
This company is for special service, and such persons as do not wish to leave the city wound do well to join promptly before the muster roll is closed.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All members of the Purcell Battery are required to report at Camp expectly.
div3.closer:
R. L. Walker,
fe 20--2t Captain Commanding.

div3.head:
Headq'rs 9th Regiment A. Ma
Richmond, February 18th, 1862.
div3.p:
order no. 16--Every male citizen between the ages of 18 and 45 not now in the active volunteer service and resident within the bounds of this regiment, (extending from 10th street west to the Corporation line) whether exempt from military duty or not, will forthwith report himself for enrollment, to the captain of his company those claiming to be exempt will also report the claim to or cause of such exemption.
The law of Virginia, passed on the 8th of February, 1862. provides.
"If any person liable to military duty shall fall to have his name enrolled by the officer appointed for that purpose for ten days after the notice or proclamation requiring such enrollment shall have been posted or published at two or more pupils place in his ward or magisterial district, he shall, unless there be a sufficient excuse for such failure, be enrolled or drafted among the first levies to be drawn from such county or corporation."
The Adjutant General, in his order of the 13th says: "Folding in this, (the enrollment of their names,) the penally imposed by law will be strictly enforced. "

The notice requiring such enrollment has been posted as prescribed by law. No previous enrollment will answer the purpose.
Because of frequent changes from volunteering and other causes, the present company rolls, though recently made are not now complete and the recent law requires an act enrollment and citizens are required, although their names may be now on the rolls, to report themselves again for enrollment.
Those residing between 10th and 4th, and Broad and Cary sts., will report to Capt Wm. F. Atkinson who may be found at the store of Ragland & Brother.

Those residing between Broad and Cary streets, and between 4th street and the western corporation line will report to Capt. Ed. R. Morriss, to be found at the office of J. Pannill, at Shockoe Warehouse.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries;: Commencing at the southwest corner of 4th and Cary sts.; thence South side of Cary street to the corporation line, thence with the corporation line to the northwest side of J. R. and K. canal thence with the northwest side of the canal to its intersection with A street; thence with the south side of A street to 4th street and thence with the western side of 4th street to the beginning — will report to Capt. Chap. L. Hebron, who may be found at the Snuff Factory, corner of 11th and Cary.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries.
Commencing at the southeast corner of 4th and Cary sts.; thence southside of Cary street to 10th street; thence west side of 10th street to James river; thence up James river to corporation line; thence with corporation line to the south side of the canal; thence with the south side of the canal to its intersection with A street and thence with the north side of A street to 4th street, and thence with the east side of 4th street to the beginning — will report to Capt. Wm. R. Sturdivant, who may be found at Gallego Mills.

Those residing between 10th and 4th streets, and between Broad street and the northern corporation line, will report to Capt. Jno. F. Stagg, or Lieut. Courtney, who may be found on 6th, between Marshall and Clay streets

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries: Commencing at the northwest corner of Broad and 4th streets; thence with the north side of Broad to Adams street; thence east side of Adams to Leigh street; thence north side of Leigh to Jefferson street; thence east side of Jefferson to Duval street; thence south side of Duval to 2d street; thence east side of 2d street to corporation line; thence with said line to 4th street, and thence west side of 4th street to the beginning — will report to Capt. S. T. Allen, on Marshall, between 6th and 7th streets.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries: Commencing at the northwest corner of 2th and Duval sts., thence north side of Duval street to Brook Avenue; thence east side of Brook Avenue to the corporation line; thence with corporation line to 2d street; thence with western side of 2d street to the beginning — will report to Captain Wm. J. Epps, who may be found at the City Hall.

Those residing within the District embraced between the following boundaries: Commencing at the corner of Broad and Adams street; thence north side of Broad street to corporation line; thence with corporation line to Brook Avenue; thence southwest side of Brook Avenue to Duval street; thence southside of Duval street to Jefferson street; thence west side of Jefferson st. to Leign street; thence south side of Lueith street to Adams street, and thence wester side of Adams street to the beginning — will report to Capt. D. W. Saunders, who may be found at his room, head of Broad street.
div3.closer: By order of Col. Evans. fe 19--3t S. T. Pendleton, Adj't.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia to raise a battalion of five companies at least, each company numbering at least one hundred men, to be mustered into the service of the Confederate States for two years, if needed so long.

This battalion is for local defence and special service in the city of Richmond, and not to be ordered away from this city.
This service is needed, or it would not be accepted.
Thus an opportunity is afforded to those, the claims of whose families and other considerations would render it extremely inconvenient to be ordered away from Richmond, to serve their country without being subjected to this inconvenience.--That they will be called in some capacity, and that right soon, no one doubts.
Persons desiring to enlist can do so by calling on the officers of the 19th regiment, or at my office, No. 7 Belvin's Block, 12th street.
Unless this battalion be raised and organized at once, the opportunity of securing the advantage above named may be last.
div3.closer:
Thos. J. Evans,
fe 19--3t Colonel 19th Regiment.

div3.p:
--The percent condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible to raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns and thick this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co.'s, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of results from the country to the city will be paid.
div3.closer:
William G. Crenshaw,
James Ellett.
Charles L. Hobson,
fe 18--ts Andrew. R Johnston.

All communications pertaining to the recruiting service, will be marked, on the upper right hand side of the envelopes which cover them, "Recruiting Service."

Those claiming to be exempt will also report the claim to or cause of such exemption.

The law of Virginia, passes on the the 8th of February, 1862, provides.
"If any person liable to military duty shall fail to have his name enrolled by the officer appointed for that purpose for ten days after the notice or proclamation requiring such enrollment, shall have been posed or published at two or more public places in his word or magisterial district, he shall, unless there be a sufficient or case for such failure be enrolled or drafted among the first levies to be drawn from such county or corporation."
The Adjutant General, in his order of the 12th, says: "Falling in this (the enrollment of their name,) the penalty imposed by law will be strictly discreet"

The notice requiring such enrollment has been posted is required by law. No previous enrollment will answer the purpose.
Because of frequent change from volunteering and other causes, the present company rolls, though recently made, are not now complete, and the recent law requires a new enrollment, and citizens are required, although their names may be now on the rolls, to report themselves again for enrollment.

8th company is bounded as follows: West by 25th street, south by James river, east by corporation line, north by Broad street. Those residing within these limits will report to Captain Jonathan Swinney.

div3.p:
--From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov., Negro Boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and happy, and is left handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail a Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.
Louisa C. Taliaferro.
Rapid Ann P. O. Culpeper county, Va.
de 12--d3t&codts

div3.head: Runaway in Jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the Jail of the county of Hanover, on the 25th day of June last, as a runaway, a Negro Woman, calling herself Milly, and says shell the property of Peter Pulliam of the city of Richmond.
Va. The said Negro is of a dark complexion, and is about four feet ten inches high and about 60 years of age and has a won on the right shoulder — a scar on same shoulder.
The said Negro had on when committed an old brown Calico dress.
The owner of the said Negro is requested to come forward, prove property pay charges, and take her away, else she will be dealt with as the law direct.
C. S. Chisholme,
Acting Jailor of Hanover county, Va.
ja 17--2aw6w

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, has been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. E. Herst, and the train left him at Burkesville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
J. W. Alsobrooks,
fe 17--1m Mill Town, Alabama.

div3.head: Runaway--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--From Mr. Edwin S. Duval, about two weeks ago, a negro slave named Wade.
He is about five feet eight inches in height, with long black hair, of very light complexion, and very pleasing in his manners.
The above reward will be paid on his delivery to me.
B. A. Cocke,
Office No. 4 Law Building,
fe 15--8t Franklin street.

div3.head: Committed to Jail as a runaway.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of the corporation of the City of Norfolk, on the 12th day of September, 1861, negro man Albert Brown.
The said negro man is five feet six and a half inches high, and weighs about 140 pounds, has a scar on the right arm about six inches long, dark complexion, and about twenty-five years old. Had on when committed gray clothing, and says he belongs to James Fisher.
Thomas J. Corprew,
fe 5--3w Sergeant City of Norfolk.

div3.head: Ranaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--A negro man named Gilbert, aged between 40 and 50 years. His color is black; whiskers grey, under the chin.
He is about six feet high; black hair.
His clothing is a black coat and plaid summer pants I bought him at Dickinson & Hill's auction room on Tuesday.
He was brought here by a gentleman named Thos. G. Neal, of North Carolina.
He left my promises Saturday afternoon, between 10 and 1 o'clock. The above reward will be paid by
H. A. Myers, 66 Main street,
fe 3--1m Or lodged in some convenient Jail

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the reward of fifty dollars for the delivery in Jail so that I get him, of my boy Moses, who run off in July last, from Mr. Henry Massie, in Orange co., where he was hired.
He has been seen since in Caroline, and also at Mr. P. A. Spotswood's in Orange, where he has a wife.
He has relations in Prince William county, near Manassas.
He is about 25 years of age, five feet 9 inches in height, dark ginger-bread color, with good front teeth, thick suit of hair, and eyes unusually red. M. P. O. is Fredericksburg, Va.
ja 22--1m Catlett Conway.

div3.head: $100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber my boy Henry, for whose apprehension and delivery to E. H. Stokes, of this place, or for his confinement in any jail, so that I get him again, I will pay the above reward.
Henry is about 23 years old, black, about five feet three inches high, and has rather a down look when spoken to. Had on when he left black coat and pants, and black felt hat. He has been seen near Bristol, on the Manassas Gap Railroad and near Cub Run Bridge.
He may be lurking around Dumfries or Richmond.
T. D. Carter,
ja 23--1m for Dr. England.
